snippet: Dozens of people were injured in a renewed outburst of protest and violence, as Egypt enters what may be a climactic stage of its turbulent shift from military rule.
abstract: Deadly clashes erupt again in Egypt, in a sign of growing tensions as the country nears end of turbulent 15-month political transition from military rule; fighting starts after protesters defy warning by the ruling military council not to approach the ministry building. Photos (M)

byline.original: By KAREEM FAHIM and LIAM STACK; David D. Kirkpatrick contributed reporting

lead_paragraph: CAIRO -- For the third time in a week, deadly clashes erupted near Egypt's Defense Ministry when military policemen fired tear gas and water cannons and threw rocks to disperse tens of thousands of protesters, in a sign of growing tensions as the country nears the end of a turbulent 15-month political transition. The latest bloodshed, which left at least two people dead and hundreds injured, started after thousands of protesters marched peacefully to the ministry, defying a warning by the ruling military council not to approach the building. The fighting started quickly, seesawed near a front line for hours, and then spread, in skirmishes that left bloodstains on the sidewalks of the surrounding neighborhood.

headline.main: Clashes Erupt Again in Egypt, Reflecting Tensions Before Transition

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: MIDDLE EAST AND NORTH AFRICA UNREST (2010- )
